narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the primary problems that historians and politicians have tried to address and their array of conflicting and interacting solutions.

I learned about the great historians and political thinkers of the ancient world. That said, I think the most important thing I learned was how to make connections between different authors and texts.

The obvious but no less important answer is that I learned a lot about the works we studied, knowledge that I think will be very useful as a basis for future classes that I take. I also improved at writing essays with clear arguments and a concrete stance on a topic.
I became better at reading long texts efficiently and meaningfully. Professor Smith also asked us to come to each class with discussion questions so I learned to read more analytically.
Understanding of ancient history, politics, and ancient historical and political methods.

I learned how to draw connections between past events and the current day. Even if a text was written during a completely different historical situation, it still has some relevance to our current political climate, which is the value of studying the classics. I also became much more comfortable with the essay writing process and developed a system of preparation and outlining that set me up for success.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very enjoyable and engaging.

The strengths of this course were the teaching, both in lecture and in seminar, as well as the high level of discussion. The main weakness of this course is that we go through the texts so fast that it's difficult to fully engage with some of them.

Strengths: The connection of topics studied with current events, the continuity within the course, and the feedback on submitted work were all very good. Professor Smith was very good at both providing his own knowledge and encouraging us to make our own insights during class discussions. 

Weaknesses: The amount of time spent on the later works in the course wasn't enough to have as good a grasp on them as we did with the earlier works, though I don't know how much there is to be done about that.

The syllabus is excellent and the mechanics of DS work like a well oiled machine. If I had one complaint, it would be that it's that the course is really not at all about history but much more about political thought. We read Herodotus and Thucydides, for example, not at all to learn about the arc of the Greek story and entirely to talk about ideology. This is fine but maybe we could get a little bit more historical understanding in addition to the philosophical angle.
This course was strong because the content was very interesting and the professor was engaging. However, the digital format obviously lends itself to some drawbacks with student engagement.

The books we read were for the most part interesting and felt extremely relevant/applicable (especially Thucydides and Tacitus). The biggest weakness of the reading list is that some books felt more suited for philosophical analysis than for studying in Historical and Political thought. However, this is a weakness of the curriculum and not Professor Smith or his teaching.

I also thought the conversation could flow more smoothly and students could be encouraged to build off of each other's ideas. It often felt that Professor Smith would ask a question, 2-3 responses were offered and then we would move on. I would prefer a class where we guide the discussion and it's more free-flowing to allow us to discuss the things we find fascinating. I also think it would feel more gratifying if students actually discussed each other's points rather than throwing out their own interpretation.

The syllabus is a strength of this course. I enjoyed the works and felt that they were all worth reading, and although I found myself more engaged by the Greek and Roman authors than with the later texts, that's just my personal preference. The subject matter of H&P is generally broader than the other two DS sections, which is a strength in that the seminar conversations can explore many different topics, but also a weakness in that it is easier for the discussions to feel unfocused at times.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminars were engaging and virtual lectures were easy to access, no improvements.

I think the virtual discussions were as successful as they could have been; however, it was difficult at times to engage with the lectures because they were asynchronous. I think it would be great if there were an option to watch the lectures live at scheduled times, which would both help with building community and keeping students on a regular schedule.

I think that the zoom class format fits well with DS classes, as they are discussion based and alleviate some of the issues with the lack of interaction that other classes have. I can't think of any improvements.

Professor Smith used canvas well by having us post discussion questions and occasionally sending out announcements. I also loved that, for the first few weeks, we had a weekly zoom "open house" which was a non-class time where we could all discuss what was on our mind. 

Professor Smith didn't usually watch the lectures and sometimes wouldn't be aware of what we already knew but that wasn't a big issue.
The size of the course was great! This class was great it's just hard to pull something off digitally.

I think the recorded lectures are actually a positive development to come out of the pandemic. I can watch the lectures at my leisure and pause/rewind them when necessary. The virtual seminars are obviously inferior to the in-person experience, but all things considered, I think they work fairly well over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Directed Studies has improved my writing and critical thinking abilities and will aid in future coursework.
I would recommend this course to anyone thinking of taking Directed Studies. Steven Smith is a fantastic professor, so if you can get into his class, you should take it.
I definitely would. I loved the works we studied, and as I mentioned before I think Professor Smith did a very good job of pushing us to think critically about them as a group.
Yes. Directed Studies is a huge commitment but, if you invest in it, you'll become a better writer and more educated human.

I would recommend Directed Studies to another student and I would recommend this section of h&p to another student if it was conducted in person. I think a lot of the magic of seminars (ie ease of conversation, collaboration, and the camaraderie of studying the same texts together in a small group/seminar format) was lost.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in history or politics. This is not strictly a history or political science course, but rather an examination of the development of intellectual thought in those two disciplines. I found it very interesting to note the difference in values between the classical and medieval worlds and our own, as well as the valuable insights they had about different systems of government and the causes of conflict.
